div1.head: Jim to M. Kiffin Rockwell May 18th 1915
div1.p:
My dear old boy you certainly are running in tough luck. Your letter has just arrived. I don’t know whether to be happy that your brother escaped being killed after such a grand and terrible fight or to be sorry that he is so wounded. God Almighty it must have been wonderful. And all of the regiment, with the exception of a handful gone — It seems too terrible, too crushing to grasp. Its great that Kiffin got out of it alive. Just think of it. Ah, he’ll be all right soon, but
for God’s sake don’t let him go back. Have him reformed. He’s done the work of many men in that fight, given all, and it was only a miracle you have him with you now. I hate like hell to think of your going back Paul. Not so bad in your old regiment, but to go in the one they order up under the hottest fire, at any and all occasions, is more than you ought to do.

Why don’t you get Kiffin transfered [sic] to the
A.A. He’ll get the best treatment there and then you can be near both him and your fiancee. I hope she’s entirely well by now. Let me know when you can about your brother and about her. Don’t go to any trouble about writing. You’ve got enough to occupy you as it is. Just a postal some time. I’ll write you as often as I can just on the chance of my letters serving to cheer you up a bit and giving you news from quarters that
“Marche bein”, eh mon vieux? I wish that I might be around some place where I might help you out in some way.
Sure. I know Thierry — Delanoue. He’s been very nice to us. Brings us English and Paris papers and slips us inside dope, which makes it very interesting. He’s a very superior sort of a man.

Just after the last letter I wrote you was finished the Boches opened up on us for fare you well. Of course it was damn
tame alongside of what you and your brother have experienced but we thought someone would get his. Two of our cars were out. The shells were coming down on the street in front of us and in the parade ground and on the wall of the caserne across from us. One of our ambulances whizzed in. Just then a shell banged down. The driver jumped and ran for it. Another hit as he turned into the court yard. He held his order card in front of him as he ran and it reminded me strongly of a 10-20-30 war
play. All he needed was some Fuller’s earth on his shoulders to pat off as he entered. We got a call for a town a couple of kilometers down to pick up some wounded from the bombardment. The next two cars went out and got back by a side street O.K. I then got a call for a Poste de Secours on the hill. The telephonist had made a mistake. There wasn’t a wounded man there, and so I started back. It was a fine sight. I could see the French artillery in action and the German shrapnel bursting over the crest. Below me in the town clouds
of smoke puffed up as a shell landed. I passed groups of soldiers watching the action from the lee ward side of the road back of stone fences. It was the first time I’ve seen anything picturesque to this damn cave [sic] fought war. The coloring and the excitement make a picture for me I will never forget. When I entered the town I noticed an air of complete desertion on the street I took. Ahead was a bang and a column of smoke, and I speeded up. I ran in hurriedly behind our
last car and just then a shell snarled down and went off the other side of the wall I was next to. My entrance into the caserne did not have the calm poise and dignified manner that it should have possessed. A little while afterwards an erstwhile Paris buss lumbered by. The fraction of a second later a shell smashed plumb in the middle of the road and we thought sure the buss would not collect fares for awhile. The driver and his aide jumped off. We beckoned them towards us and in they
came headlong. It was just like a bunch running for shelter from a heavy rainstorm.

A 220 landed yesterday ten feet from one of our cars that was running along the road, but by the grace of God and and [sic] the rest of the Olympian gang it didn’t go off. They’ve got it roped in now for no one dares to pick it up. It seems they are like skunks and go off when you pet em [sic].

I’m driving the contagious car now and will be relieved the 20th[.] I suppose
I’ll get the Australian Zing and various other delightful ills.
Wish I could tell you about some of the Military dope out here but I can’t of course. To day we took up a box of little crosses. You probably know what that indicates[.]
We are now living entirely at our advance point. What was our former base has been given up. I think I’ll get a billet up here too but don’t know yet.

Six new men are coming
up with as many cars to morrow, or the next day and its going to be damn good fun watching them get their first bunch of shells. They certainly do make one nervous when one is on the open road and no place to crawl behind. We’ve all been very fortunate however.

If I can locate our American friend to day I’ll send this letter by regular post as from him so it will get to you with greater dispatch. Otherwise it may not go until
to morrow for we have to hand them to our marechal des logis who won’t come up here. He’s been wounded twice and thinks he’s done enough. Can’t say I blame him the hell of a lot, tho [sic] it seems queer.
A deurain [sp?], mon vieux and boune chance pour Kiffin. My best to him.
